Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Electoral Uncertainty and Policy Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
How does electoral competition over majority control influence a legislature's ability to draft and pass meaningful legislation? Today, even the most casual observers of politics understand legislative gridlock to be a key feature of the modern legislative politics. Since at least the 1990s, scholars, media pundits, and even politicians have called attention to these institutions' lack of productivity, most often attributing the phenomenon to growing ideological polarization between the two major political parties. But while the widening gulf between the political parties --and the influence it likely has on policy change and legislative gridlock-- is undeniable, this project examines a crucial factor that most accounts of legislative gridlock have ignored: the rise in competition over majority control. This project develops a new theory of policy change that articulates and tests the conditions under which this sort of electoral competition encourages or stymies policy change, beyond what polarization alone might predict. Ultimately, the project would provide an explanation for why even popular legislation often fails to gain traction, and why polarization does not itself always predict a legislature's levels of productivity. Tying legislative productivity to electoral competition in this way would also carry with it potential normative, constitutional, and policy implications regarding topics such as the frequency of elections and the appropriateness of partisan agenda-setting.

How does competition over majority control alter the strategic calculus of partisan agenda-setters in a legislature and what influence may it have on aggregate policy change? Beginning with Mayhew's (1973) seminal work, electoral dynamics have remained at the heart of nearly all modern analysis of legislative politics. Yet in spite of this centrality, and in spite of the sharp differences in electoral competitiveness over majority control American political history (Lee 2016), little theorizing or empirical research has delineated how electoral dynamics influence the policy change process. This project ties together key insights from both the electoral and policy change literatures in political science to create a new, elections-adjusted model of policy change and provide a series of novel empirical tests of this theory. First, using new data measuring contemporaneous beliefs regarding macro-level competitiveness, this project examines how well my elections-adjusted policy change model predicts legislative productivity since 1940, compared to current models (e.g., Krehbiel 1998, Cox and McCubbins 2005). Second, the project leverages the reauthorizations process and new, interest-group-based estimates of bill locations to examine whether and how macro-level competition influences bill-level decisionmaking regarding policy change. Finally, capitalizing on the broad coverage of bill location estimates (including locations of bills that failed to receive a roll call vote), this project examines how macro-level competition influences the agenda-setting decisions made by majority leaders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Partisan conflict and competition have, by most accounts, enveloped nearly every aspect of American political life. From the news media to fundraising networks to confirmation politics and more, both scholarly research and popular accounts have underscored the central role that party reputation plays in individual political behavior. But while scholars have underscored the importance of heightened partisan considerations for most aspects of the representational process, the implications of partisan conflict and competition for policymaking and legislative gridlock are less clear. This dissertation research details and provides evidence for the fundamental influences of partisan competition on policymaking and policy output in American legislatures. More specifically, the research underscores that, while ideological polarization indeed plays an important role in congressional policymaking and legislative gridlock, concern about the favorability of future elections fundamentally alters legislators’ policymaking considerations.

The funded research makes both theoretical and empirical contributions within political science and other social scientific fields. Theoretically, the research underscores how solely policy-motivated legislators may choose against policy changes they prefer, if they consider how the policymaking environment will evolve after an upcoming election. Operationally, the research adds a dynamic component to traditional spatial models of policymaking, showing that if legislators believe they will face a favorable policymaking environment in the future, they should willfully reject favorable policy changes. Given that today’s heightened partisan competition—whereby parties frequently encounter the possibility that the policymaking environment will change dramatically in two short years—these theoretical predictions are of direct importance for understanding contemporary policymaking in the U.S.

In order to test the implications drawn from the project’s theoretical model, the funded research has contributed not only a series of compelling findings, but also several useful datasets for future use by political scientists, economists, journalists, and others. First, in order to examine the influences of electoral expectations on policymaking, the PI developed an original set of majority-control probabilities for the House and Senate, from 1940 to 2018. These estimates were developed by compiling share prices from the Iowa Electronic Market (in order to capture contemporaneous beliefs about majority control probabilities), and then interpolated using a compilation of variables such as generic congressional vote polls, economic information, and political cycle indicators. Given the granular and long-ranging nature of these data, they should be quite useful for any scholar examining the influences of electoral expectations on various political dynamics.

In order to examine the aforementioned policymaking ramifications of partisan competition, the PI also developed a new data set of over 1,000 status quo and proposal location estimates for bills before Congress, 2007-2018. These estimates enabled the research to test the spatial predictions of the theoretical model. In addition to enabling these tests, however, they constitute the largest compilation of congressional bill and status quo location estimates ever produced to date. Given the central importance of legislative location estimates to testing the many spatial models of legislatures, these data will equip future researchers with a valuable tool in testing empirical implications of theoretical models.

Finally, using these unique data, the funded research provides a series of important findings. In particular, consistent with predictions from the theoretical model, the findings show that legislators respond to changing expectations for majority control. When legislators expect that agenda-setters will slow down the policymaking process (because a better configuration will arrive after the election), legislators are much less likely to offer viable legislation—legislation that could conceivably pass, if brought up for a vote. Similarly, if they expect agenda-setters to move legislation, legislators are more likely to offer viable legislation—and less likely to offer hopeless “message” legislation.

Taken together, the funded research has provided theoretical and empirical findings, as well as data and measurements, that will be of broad use scholars interested in American democracy, legislatures, and policymaking.
